title: 108_s1029
content: The title of the act is the "Israeli-Palestinian Peace Enhancement Act of 2003". The Israeli-Palestinian Peace Enhancement Act of 2003 emphasizes the importance of the security of Israel as a national interest of the United States and the need for a peaceful Middle East free of violence and terrorism. It acknowledges the Palestinian people's suffering due to leaders resorting to violence, and expresses support for a two-state solution with Israel and Palestine living in peace and security. President George W. Bush's vision for the region is also referenced. President George W. Bush outlined a vision for peace in the Middle East region after a change in Palestinian leadership. The Palestinian state must be reformed, peaceful, and democratic, renouncing the use of terror. The Palestinian Legislative Council confirmed Mahmoud Abbas as the first prime minister, focusing on security and addressing the unauthorized possession of weapons. Mahmoud Abbas, the Palestinian Authority President, addresses concerns about terrorism and expresses willingness to make concessions for peace with Israel. The purposes of this title are to express Congress's support for recognizing a Palestinian state and to show willingness to provide economic and humanitarian aid after Palestinians achieve reforms and peace with Israel. Congress acknowledges the need for Palestinian government reforms outlined by President Bush, economic assistance post-reforms, praises the appointment of Mahmoud Abbas as prime minister, and urges security measures for peace with Israel. The United States Administration should work towards a two-state solution for the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, ensuring peace and security within recognized boundaries. It is crucial for national security to achieve a just resolution based on UN Security Council Resolutions 242 and 338. SEC. 5. RECOGNITION OF A PALESTINIAN STATE. The sense of Congress is that the US should not recognize a Palestinian state until a new leadership not involved in terrorism is elected, and the entity shows commitment to peaceful coexistence with Israel, ends anti-Israel incitement, and takes measures against terrorism and terrorist financing. The Palestinian entity must cooperate with Israeli security, govern effectively, promote peace with Israel in education, and prevent anti-Israel incitement. SEC. 6. LIMITATION ON ASSISTANCE TO A PALESTINIAN STATE. Amends the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 to include a new section limiting assistance to a Palestinian state. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 includes a new section limiting assistance to a Palestinian state. Assistance can only be provided during a certified period, with exceptions for humanitarian aid, development assistance through NGOs, and support for reforming Palestinian institutions. The Israeli-Palestinian Peace Enhancement Act of 2003 allows the President to waive limitations on assistance to a Palestinian state if it is in the national interest of the United States. Congressional notification is required before providing assistance to a Palestinian state under this Act or any other provision of law. The Act also includes provisions for a sunset clause after ten years and certification requirements for a binding international peace agreement between Israel and the Palestinians. The Israeli-Palestinian Peace Enhancement Act of 2003 outlines conditions for a permanent resolution between Israel and Palestine, including renunciation of claims, refugee resolutions, and a democratically elected Palestinian government with exclusive authority. President Bush outlined conditions for a permanent resolution between Israel and Palestine in his June 24, 2002 speech, including renouncing violence against Israel, dismantling terrorist groups, engaging in security cooperation, and refraining from inciting acts against Israel. The President must provide recertifications every 6 months for a 10-year period to ensure that a foreign entity meets specific criteria, including renouncing violence against Israel, having a non-terror compromised leadership, being demilitarized, and having no alliances threatening Israel's security. If unable to recertify, a report with reasons must be submitted to Congress. The President must provide recertifications every 6 months for a 10-year period to ensure a foreign entity meets specific criteria. A certification under subsection (c) is in effect unless the President determines requirements are not being met and submits a report to Congress with reasons. SEC. 7. AUTHORIZATION OF ASSISTANCE TO A PALESTINIAN STATE. Authorization of assistance to a Palestinian state is added to the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961. The President is authorized to provide assistance to a Palestinian state to improve the economy and living conditions by supporting activities such as economic development, promoting democracy, developing water resources, assisting in security cooperation, and helping with the compensation of Palestinian refugees. Authorization of appropriations is provided for these purposes. The Secretary of State will coordinate international assistance for Palestinians through donors conferences to ensure timely commitments from other countries, institutions, and organizations. Assistance must be used for its intended purposes. The Secretary of State will coordinate international assistance for Palestinians to prevent aid from going to designated terrorist organizations. A report detailing these efforts must be submitted annually to relevant congressional committees. During the reporting period, each country and organization provided amounts of aid to a Palestinian state or Palestinians.
